docs.abstract: In “Danger Close: The Battle of Long Tan,” a filmmaker’s dramatization has earned both praise and pushback from the soldiers who survived the attack 53 years ago.
docs.snippet: In “Danger Close: The Battle of Long Tan,” a filmmaker’s dramatization has earned both praise and pushback from the soldiers who survived the attack 53 years ago.
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s been 53 years since the Battle of Long Tan, and Harry Smith, 86, remembers it all — the torrential rain that obscured his view of his soldiers and the men they were facing, the relentless echo of bullets and artillery that shredded the ground around them and the smell of cordite in the air.

headline.main: What Vietnam Veterans Think of the New Film About Their War

docs.abstract: Determine whether the rhythm is steady or sporadic. A whistling before the pop is another giveaway.
docs.snippet: Determine whether the rhythm is steady or sporadic. A whistling before the pop is another giveaway.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Listen for the cadence,” says Scott Beisner, a public-safety specialist for ShotSpotter, which has installed acoustic sensors in more than 100 cities to capture and locate where shots are fired. “When somebody pulls a trigger, they tend to pull it in a fairly steady rhythm until the end, when their finger gets tired,” Beisner says. A series of evenly spaced bang-bang-bang sounds is much more likely to be a gun than the more sporadic ba-bang, ba-ba-ba-ba-bang of firecrackers. When sensors record a gunlike noise in, say, Cape Town or Chicago, software analyzes it for the sonic signatures of gunfire, and within seconds Beisner and his team listen to those audio files and look at those recorded waveforms at their office in Newark, Calif. Confirmed or suspected gunfire incidents are then reported to the local police.

headline.main: How to Tell Gunfire From Fireworks
headline.print_headline: How to Tell Gunfire From Fireworks

docs.abstract: Give your dough an impossibly tender, cakelike crumb.
docs.snippet: Give your dough an impossibly tender, cakelike crumb.
docs.lead_paragraph: I know what you might be thinking, that you don’t really need another biscuit technique, not now. Not when you’ve got that one you already make, tender with lard and chilled buttermilk. Not when you’ve got a whole routine, say, cutting up butter and letting it fall directly into a frozen bowl. Not when you’ve gotten this far just fine on tubs of shortening that never let you down. With biscuits, you find your way by making them over and over, repeating the process until you really get a feel for the dough — the cold fat in long smudged pieces, cushioned in barely bound flour — no part of it tacky and overworked, but no part of it dry and cracking. And once you reach it, the soft, lumpy perfection of biscuit dough, the dusty, rolled-out surface like a sweaty arm that’s been resting right under the air-conditioner, you tend to stick with whatever technique got you there.

headline.main: Ricotta Will Change Everything You Know About Biscuits

docs.abstract: Hawks in Israel and America have spent more than a decade agitating for war against the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program. Will Trump finally deliver?
docs.snippet: Hawks in Israel and America have spent more than a decade agitating for war against the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program. Will Trump finally deliver?
docs.lead_paragraph: In July of 2017, the White House was at a crossroads on the question of Iran. President Trump had made a campaign pledge to leave the “terrible” nuclear deal that President Barack Obama negotiated with Tehran, but prominent members of Trump’s cabinet spent the early months of the administration pushing the mercurial president to negotiate a stronger agreement rather than scotch the deal entirely. Thus far, the forces for negotiation had prevailed.

headline.main: The Secret History of the Push to Strike Iran

byline.original: By Ronen Bergman and Mark Mazzetti

docs.abstract: Traditional recipes for amba take days. But this hacked recipe delivers the condiment’s hot, sour, salty tang in less than an hour.
docs.snippet: Traditional recipes for amba take days. But this hacked recipe delivers the condiment’s hot, sour, salty tang in less than an hour.
docs.lead_paragraph: The only problem with amba — the habit-forming, incandescently bright mango pickle found on the bar of every falafel shop — is how long it takes to make. Days, if you’re doing it the old-fashioned way: salting pieces of mango and letting the jars sit in the sun, until the fruit has softened, released all its juices and lightened in color. This salt-preserved fruit, after about five days, is mixed with a powerful sludge of spices that include turmeric and crushed fenugreek and cumin seeds, staining the pickle with color and deepening its flavor — a hot, sour, salty tang that amplifies as the pickle continues to ferment for a few more days. It’s a process, but the result is both intense and delicious, the kind of thing you taste once and want to keep tucked away in the fridge at all times.

headline.main: What Do You Do With an Unripe Mango? Pickle It
headline.print_headline: What Do You Do With an Unripe Mango? Pickle It
